A DISCOURSE UPON I Peter IV. VIII. Wherein the Power and Efficacy OF CHARITY. As it is a Means to procure the Pardon of Sin, Is EXPLAINED and VINDICATED,

TO All Good Christians, who≈øe Faith is made Effectual by CHARITY, The AUTHOR Dedicateth this DISCOURSE; Wi≈øhing Them Increa≈øe of that mo≈øt Divine, mo≈øt Chri≈øtian, and mo≈øt Spiritual Grace.

q.p: And above all things have fervent Charity among your ≈øelves, for Charity ≈øhall (or will) cover a multitude of Sins.

div.p:
AS in the Ethnick Theology of the Greek Poets, we read of a Famous Triade of Graces, reported to be the Daughters of Jupiter: So the Apo≈øtle St Paul makes mention of a certain Trinity of Chri≈øtian Graces, all ≈øpecial Fruits and Daughters of the Holy Spirit. 1 Cor. 13.13. And now abideth Faith, Hope, and Charity, but the greate≈øt of the≈øe is Charity. And that may duely be e≈øteemed the greater, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or greate≈øt
of the Three, in many re≈øpects, be≈øides that which the Apo≈øtle ≈øeems ≈øpecially to aim at, in that Text, viz. That of continuance and duration in another Life, after the Expiration of the other Two. For Charity is a Vertue of the greate≈øt Perfection that can be, and mo≈øt highly de≈øerving the Name of Grace. Gratia gratis data, & gratia gratum faciens; As freely given as any other and mo≈øt gratefull to God and Man. This Charity is the Root, Ground, and Foundation of all Chri≈øtian Piety, as is intimated by the words of the Apo≈øtle, Eph. 3.17, 18.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Radicati & Fundati.
That ye, being rooted and grounded in love, &c. It is indeed the end, and fruit of the other Two. Faith teaches it, Hope excites and cheri≈øhes it. It is al≈øo of greate≈øt Extent, extending both to God and Man; All Men, our ≈øelves, our Friends, and Enemies. Faith and Hope will be antiquated by po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, ≈øight, and fruition, but Charity is a thing that we ≈øhall carry with us into the other World, where we ≈øhall improve and keep it for ever. 'Tis the end of the Commandment, 1 Tim. 1.5. and the fulfilling
of the Law. Gal. 5.14. For all the Law is fulfilled in one word, even in this, Thou ≈øhalt love, &c. That one little Mono≈øyllable Love, is a perfect abbreviation of the whole Code and Pandects of the Divine Law. The fir≈øt and the great Commandment is this, Mat. 22.37, &c. Thou ≈øhalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart and with all thy ≈øoul, with all thy mind, and with all thy might. He that truly loves God, will not break any of his Commandments willfully; and he that doth not love him, cannot keep any of them. 1 Jo 5.3. 'Tis the bond of perfection, both of Nature and Grace, of Humanity and Divinity: A loving Di≈øpo≈øition is that which

I ≈øhall conclude the pre≈øent Encomium of this Grace, in Three Words: ≈øhewing that it is the mo≈øt Divine, the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian, the mo≈øt Spiritual Vertue.

p.q:
1. The mo≈øt Divine, For God is Love, ≈øaith the mo≈øt Loving, and beloved Di≈øciple twice over in one Chapter, 1 Jo. 4.7, 8, 16. Beloved let us love one another,
for Love is of God, And every one that loveth is born of God, and knoweth God. He that loveth not, knoweth not God, for God is Love. And we have known and believed the Love that God hath to us: God is Love, and he that dwelleth in Love, dwelleth in God, and God in him.

So did ≈øome of the olde≈øt of the Greek Poets call the Supream Deity, and the Original of all Beings by the name of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Love. And ≈øo Plato and his Di≈øciples call the Fir≈øt Per≈øon in their Trinity „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øelf goodne≈øs. 'Tis by this Vertue of Love, that we are made partakers of the Divine Nature mo≈øt eminently, that being the Highe≈øt Perfection of the Image of God, that we are capable of: For God is Love, not cau≈øally only, but e≈ø≈øentially. Other Graces are from him, Quicquid in Deo e≈øt, Deus e≈øt. but this is in him; and what≈øoever is ≈øo, is him≈øelf. Other Graces of Humility, temperance, and even tho≈øe two mentioned by the Apo≈øtle together with this, Faith, and Hope, do connotate ≈øomething of imperfection, incompetible to the Divine Nature: But Love is Pure, and Perfect Goodne≈øs.
Our Engli≈øh Name of God comes from Good. And 'tis this Vertue of Love that makes us partakers of the Name of God in a qualified ≈øen≈øe, Homo homini Deus, one man is a petty God to another, as he is a Benefactor. Such only were the Hero's, and minor Deities of the Heathens: Such as had been Eminent Benefactors to their Country in their Lives, and were therefore Deified after their Death. Such were all earthly Gods, Kings, and Princes, they were called „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Benefactors. Luke 22.25. So the word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ u≈øed for a Prince, and rendred by the Septuagint „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , & „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ doth primarily ≈øignifie a Liberal Magnificent Benefactor.

I ≈øay therefore, that Love is the mo≈øt Divine Grace, as having mo≈øt of the Name, and Nature of God in it. On the contrary, tho≈øe Vicious Di≈øpo≈øitions, which are mo≈øt directly oppo≈øite to Love, are the mo≈øt Satanical and Diabolical, malice, hatred, envy, &c.

2. Charity is the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Virtue, mo≈øt ≈øtrictly charged by Chri≈øt him≈øelf, by his ≈øpecial Command, and ≈øignally expre≈ø≈øed in his Singular Example, Jo. 15.12. This is my Commandment that ye love one another, as I have loved you. The Pronoun my, is Emphatical, ≈øignifying the Special Weight that he puts upon this Commandment. And this is the rea≈øon, (as St Hierom reports) that was given by the Beloved Di≈øciple St John, when the que≈øtion was put to him by his Auditors, why he did ≈øo much in ulcate that Precept in his Preaching, Filioli diligite alterutrum, Little children love one another; he an≈øwered. quia e≈øt preceptum Domini, becau≈øe it was the Command of his Lord, meaning the Special and Principal Commandment, and that, which being obeyed, would ≈øecure the fulfilling of all the re≈øt, that concerned humane ≈øociety; and was

The fir≈øt Argument which I ≈øhall produce for the Truth of this Doctrine, ≈øhall be taken from tho≈øe Texts, which ≈øpeak of ≈øuch an Act of Charity, as is more commonly under≈øtood in this Text; namely, That whereby we Cover the ≈øins of others, by Forgiving them their Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes again≈øt our ≈øelves. When ye ≈øtand praying, forgive, if ye have ought again≈øt any, that your Father which is in Heaven may forgive you your Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes: But if you do not forgive, neither will your Father which is in Heaven forgive your Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes. our Saviour hath taught us? Forgive us our Debts, i. e. our ≈øins, as we forgive our Debters, i. e. them that tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt us, Luke 11.4. Where the Particles As, in the one Evangeli≈øt, and For, in the other, do ≈øignifie the ≈øame thing, namely, A Motive u≈øed by our Saviours direction to promote the Effect of our Petition, confirmed by an expre≈øs Promi≈øe, Luke 6.37. Forgive, and ye ≈øhall be forgiven. Add to this from the beginning of the ≈øame Sermon of our Ble≈ø≈øed Saviour, Mat. 5.7. Ble≈ø≈øed are the Mercifull, for they ≈øhall obtain Mercy, and as Mercy in us is a Branch of Charity; ≈øo the Covering or Pardon of ≈øins is an eminent Part of that Mercy that is to be obtained thereby. For he ≈øhall have Judgement without Mercy, that hath ≈øhewed no Mercy, and Mercy rejoyceth again≈øt Judgement. And as in this fir≈øt Branch of the Text, the word Mercy twice u≈øed doth plainly ≈øignifie

In each part of this De≈øcription of the di≈øtributive Ju≈øtice, or Judgement of God in the latter day, a common Synechdoche of the Part for the Whole, mu≈øt be under≈øtood,

For neither will Charity be re≈øpected as the only rea≈øon, or condition of the Reward, but therewith al≈øo all other Chri≈øtian Vertues, and Good Works, e≈øpecially that of an unfeigned Faith, as the Root of them all. But ≈øince it hath plea≈øed our Saviour, who is him≈øelf to be Judge at that day, to ≈øpecifie the≈øe two oppo≈øite Practi≈øes as the only In≈øtances of the rea≈øon of his future Judgement, we have ≈øufficient ground to conclude, that they will be e≈øpecially, though not only, con≈øidered by him in that Judgement.

The ≈øame Synechdoche of the Part for the Whole, nece≈ø≈øary to be under≈øtood in the words of our Saviour, which we have la≈øt mentioned, is no le≈øs nece≈ø≈øary to be under≈øtood in all Promi≈øes of the ≈øame Reward to any particular Vertue, or ≈øort of

But although in the promi≈øes of this reward to any particular Vertue, or ≈øort of Good Works, there be a nece≈ø≈øity of the fore≈øaid Synechdoche, yet in the Threatnings of Judgments to particular Vices, there is no nece≈ø≈øity of any ≈øuch Figure.
